bibl.title: George Hawkins v. The United States of America. Petition
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.ab: IN THE UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT, IN AND FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of George Hawkins for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
div1.p: TO THE HONORABLE C.S.HANFORD, JUDGE OF THE ABOVE ENTITLED COURT. The petition of George Hawkins respectfully shows to your Honor;

That the cause of pretense of the restraint of your said petitioner, according to the best of the knowledge and belief of the petitioner, is as follows;- That on the 23rd day of January, A.D. 1901. your said petitioner was indicted by the Grand Jury in and for the Second Division, District of Alaska, for the crime of robbery, a certified copy of which said indictment is hereto annexed, marked "Exhibit A" and made a part of this petition.

That thereaftr such proceedings were had and taken in the said United States District Court in and for the District of Alaska, Second Division, upon said indictment that the said petitioner was tried upon and convicted of the charge contained in said indictment, and thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in the said United States District Court in and for the District of Alaska, Second Division, that your said petitioner was by the judgment of the said United States District Court. in and for the District of Alaska, Second Division, sentenced to be confined in the United States Penitentiary at McNeil's Island, in the State of Washington, for a period of fifteen years; that thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said United States District Court, in and for the District of Alaska, Second Division, upon the said judgment and sentence that the Honorable Arthur H. Moyes, Judge of the United States District Court, in and for the District of Alaska, Second Division, issued

a committment upon said judgment and sentence, a certified copy of which committment is hereto annexed, marked "Exhibit B" and made a part hereof. That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in the said United States District Court, in and for the District of Alaska, Second Division, that said petitioner prosecuted a writ of error from that said judgment and sentence to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, in and for the Ninth Circuit; that thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in the said United States Circuit Court of Appeals that an application was made for and on behalf of your said petitioner to have your said petitioner admitted to bail pending the hearing and determination of the cause of your said petitioner upon said writ of error in the said Circuit Court of Appeals; that thereafter such proceedings were had and taken upon said application to have your said petitioner admitting to bail, that the Honorable Wm. W. Morrow as Circuit Judge, and one of the Judges of the said Circuit Court of Appeals, made an order in the said cause of your said petitioner then pending in the said Circuit court of Appeals upon said writ of error, that a supersedeas be granted therein and that your petitioner furnish or cause to be furnished a bond in the sum of Five Thousand Dollars, conditioned according to law, subject to the approval of the United States District Judge for the District of Washington, or the Judge or acting Judge of the District Court for the District of Alaska, Second Division, and that upon the approval of said bond your said petitioner be admitted to bail pending the determination of said writ of error, or until the further order of the said United States Circuit Court of Appeals; that thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in the said United States Circuit Court of Appeals that the sad bond of your said petitioner was reduced to the sum of Three Thousand Dollars, conditioned as aforesaid and to be approved as aforesaid; and but your said petitioner alleges that by reason of his being without friends and unacquainted in the State of Washington, he was unable to furnish the said bond pending the determination of his said cause upon said writ of error; that therafter such proceedings were had and taken in the said United States Circuit Court of Appeals, upon said indictment, and upon record in said cuase, that the said United States Circuit Court

of Appeals did on the 5th day of June, A.D., 1902, reverse the said judgment and sentence and remand the said cause for a new trial; that thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in the said cause upon said indictment, that the said Circuit Court of Appeals issued a mandate in said cause, a certified copy of which said mandate is hereto annexed, marked "Exhibit C" and made a part hereof, which said mandate from the Circuit Court of Appeals in the said cause was filed with the Clerk of the United States District Court, in and for the District of Alaska, Second Division, on the 31st day of July, 1902, that thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in the said United States District Court, in and for the District of Alaska, Second Division, that on the 14th day of October, A.D. 1902, the Honorable Alfred S. Moore, Judge of the United States District Court, in and for the District of Alaska, Second Division, made an order admitting the said petitioner to bail in the sum of Three Thousand Dollars, a certified copy of which said order is hereto annexed, marked "Exhibit D" and made a part hereof; that thereafter such proceedings were had and taken upon the said indictment in said cause, that on the 14th day of October, A. D., 1902, the Honorable Alfred S. Moore, Judge of the United States District Court, in and for the district of Alaska, Second Division, made an order fixing the said cause upon said indictment, for trial for the first Monday in September, A.D., 1903. a certified copy of which said order is hereto annexed, marked "Exhibit E" and made a part hereof.
That your said petitioner alleges that his said imprisonment and restraint is illegal, and that said illegality consists in this;

A.-That the said judgment and sentence of the said United States District Court, in and for this District of Alaska, Second Division, having been reversed, and your said petitioner having been granted a new trial by the said United States Circuit Court of Appeals, the said committment issued upon the said judgment is illegal, void and of no force or effect, and in truth and fact your said petitioner is not confined or

imprisoned by the said Warden of the said United States Penitentiary at McNeil's Island, under and by virtue of any legal or valid process, issued on any final judgment of a Court of competent jurisdiction.
B.-That your said petitioner has not been granted a speedy trial upon said indictment, and is deprived of his liberty without due process of law.

C.-That by reason of your said petitioner's illegal restraint and confinement in said United States Penitentiary at McNeil's Island, in the State of Washington, and without the jurisdiction of the said United States District Court in and for the District of Alaska, Second Division, your said petitioner has been denied and deprived of the right and opportunity to procure bail upon said indictment.

D.-That under and according to the laws of the District of Alaska now in force, the Sureties upon bail after indictment, are required to qualify and justify before a magistrate of this District of Alaska, and to make oath among other things that they are residents and inhabitants of the district of Alaska; and your said petitioner alleges that he is wholly unacquainted with any of the residents and inhabitants of Alaska save and except those residing at Nome in the Second Division, District of Alaska, and that he is without friends or acquaintances in the State of Washington, and that navigation between McNeil's Island in the State of Washington, where your said petitioner is now restrained of his liberty, and Nome, in the district of Alaska, where your said petitioner could obtain bail, is now closed, and owing to the close of navigation and the lack of other means of transportation your said petitioner cannot now be taken to Nome in the District of Alaska for trial upon said indictment before the 15th day of June, 1903; that by reason of the aforesaid facts, and by reason of the failure of the United States to comply with the said mandate of the said Circuit Court of Appeals, and remand your said petitioner to the said town of Nome in the Second Division, District of Alaska, for a new trial, your said petitioner has been deprived of the opportunity to obtain and has been and is unable to obtain bail upon said indictment; that your said petitioner is in ill health and
unless he is granted his liberty and released from confinement, will be in great danger of loosing his life.

Wherefor your said petitioner prays that a writ of habeas corpus may be granted, directed to the said Warden of the United States Pentientiary at McNeil's Island, in the State of Washington, commending him to have the body of your said petitioner before this Honorable Court at the time and place therein to be specified, to do and receive what shall then and there be considered by your Honor concerning him, together with the time and cause of his detention, and the said writ; and that your said petitioner may be restored to his liberty and discharged from custody.
div1.ab: State of Washington County of King.
div1.p: I, James E. Fenton, being duly sworn says;- That I am the Attorney of record for the above named petitioner, George Hawkins; that I have read the foregoing petition, know the contents thereof and the allegations are true as I verily believe; that I make this verification in behalf of the said petitioner for the reason that all the material allegations in the said petition are within my personal knowledge.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 5th day of November, 1902.
div1.ab: Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
